notesStmt.note: [NOTES: the document contains two typed word-lists – one dated May 1970 and the other December 1971 – and a hand-written letter dated 30th November 1970.]
[NOTES: the accents were added by hand (black ink). There are also some hand-written notes in the margin of the first list. They may have been added by the informant himself.]
[NOTES: quite a few items are listed more than once even within the same list, sometimes using different spelling.]

entry.def: feeling important or complacent. [NOTES: note in the margin – (toiseil). (black ink)]
the reef in a sail next the sheet.
Anns a bhuile trot – [NOTES: note in the margin – ? (black ink)]
(Sleamhuinn a chlach a th’ann an ursuinn a Taighe Mhoir.)
(Comhairle Glag Scain, rud nach buin dhut na buin dha.)
(Sean fhacal, ged a sharaicheadh e cha do bhriagnaicheadh e.)
[sic] As a’ chùl tamh – saying something out of the blue.
an angry look, often applied to a dog with his hair ruffled. [NOTES: note in the margin – confhadh, rage, fury (N. Uist). (black ink)]
a stagger or a trip in wrestling.
straggling end of cloth, or a corner of a shawl air a beannan (folded cornerwise).
Toirt tannt dha – taunt, maybe; casting up.
ripple to the nose of a fish swimming near the surface; gut. Fishing gut.
urchin or a wet untidy fellow. Tha thu air do mheabaineachadh – like somebody who has been out in the rain.
the shiver above the fire in the open on a hot day.
the cooing of a bird, or even of a baby. [NOTES: note in the margin – (N. Uist). (black ink)]
edging in on something. [NOTES: note in the margin – Dhinn Dh’ighn (N. Uist). (black ink)]
a sea shell about the size of a small hen’s egg and shaped like so.
Nuair theid na mearlaich thar a cheile this [sic] an t-ionracan na chuid.
a palm-full of grain more customary as màm sil. Also mam [sic] for a squat hill.
making a grumph [sic] or a sudden bark from a dog. [NOTES: two variants of the same word?]
measurement of tweed usually from the tip of the middle finger to the knuckle joint.
the jack in a pack of cards.
an expression used by certain families in a certain district, when wishing to emphasise (as indeed it was).
Tilp a nall – slip over as for a fly visit, or better tuilp.
beefy, as: Nach ann air a tha bhaltag.
a pole. The pole erected when there was seaweed on the shore in the days when seaweed had to be air a roinn.
miod mhor – proud or showing off.
Gun chrid – quite healthy. Gun chrid Mhathar (emphasis again).
wide open. Dh’fhagadh an dorus straoint [sic] fosgailte.
movement. Cha d’thug iad tuilg aiste.
expectancy. Duil thairis – giving up expecting.
an article used for winding yarn.
possibly hopper – in the mill where the grain is poured to be ground by the bra (the grinding stone).
roughing the [grinding] stone with a pickaxe when it gets too polished.

weeping but also maybe caoineachadh – making it finer. (In making a bag for bagpipes after the skin was shred of the wool it was placed in alum and then dried. It was then stiff, but had to be teased and rubbed by the hands until it was like chamois, air a chaoineachadh.)
trouble. Leig e mi a geomhail – he relieved me.
drain on the roadside to allow water to run off.
a blow. Bheir dha gefoir, spleoc e. (maybe local expressions)
an electric storm, where lightning strikes.
thickly set, particularly referring to hay and corn as left by the scythe.
sound. Cha chuala mi deùrd [sic] – I did not hear a murmur.
like a horse showing anger by flattening the ears.
horse rolling over to scratch its back.
without energy. Na lunn-lann – without ambition, etc.
a tripping. Gus a tuisleadh – expecting soon.
a caller who is also a moucher [sic] [moocher?].
a very small egg, either the first or last when the hen starts or stops laying.
poor health. [NOTES: the definition added by hand (blue ink).]
showing signs of anger. De an colg a th’ort?
a snare made by horse hair on a frame to catch small birds.
the stick under a horse’s tail with ropes to the saddle to keep it from slipping over the horse’s neck.
in the height of the rain.
trifle of a coin. Cha torain bonn spuaichde air.
such as: Lochradh le fallas – sweating heavily.
Beoltainn chaom, mhin, mhaltain bhla agus turadh an treas la / Ach ma’s uisge ’s gaoth bhios ann, ’s buailteach gur e ganntar a bhios ann. [NOTES: note in the margin – (buailteach). (blue ink)]
small bird with shrill voice, found on sand beaches.
the bit in a horse’s mouth.
the drawing chain on a cart shaft.
the bend on the saddle for an druim [q.v.].
the draw pin for the plough.
drawing chains for the plough. Hence: sineadh for ploughing in some places.
the board on the plough for turning the furrow or uiridh.
the Mass vestments in R.C. Church.
the rope across the corner of a thatched roof.
the tips on each end of the roof of a thatched house.
the end of a fence ending in a loch.
a loud report like a very loud shot from a gun.
directing or driving a beast [in] a certain direction.
a field or stretch of land as well as a battle.
making a fuss or one like a dog does.
applied to an ear playing piper.
undependable. Duine moisgeadach. [NOTES: note in the margin – mobhsgaideach. (black ink)]
Cuir ann a geomhail – put on the spot or in trouble.
a person over keen on working.
looking angry. Coinig air – he looks angry.
understanding. Duine aig a bheil toinisg.
the juice of boiled potatoes. Leighe [sic] a bhuntata.
tripping one as in wrestling. Cuir na bacaig air.
when scything corn placing the “beum” in place.
a very small egg, as the last egg for the season.
trap for catching birds, made with horse hair in a frame.
(ca-bheil) place made in the river to hold the net when poaching.
the calm period at the end of autumn.
a bachelor (best man at a marriage).
at the height of the rain.
natural to one’s surroundings. Theid duthchas an aghaidh nan creig.
Chan ’eil stuadh na bogha bristeadh orm – in no hurry.
messing a thing, especially something being eaten.
a cord to shorten the kirt [sic] [kilt?] (going round below the hips).
[?] egging on or urging. [NOTES: it looks like the word was spelled ‘tutanach’ originally but then ‘d’ was typed over ‘c’… or the other way round!]
playing cards; the two to the fives only.
a fixed rock in the ground, as against a loose stone.
gaoradh (gurradh) air a cheile – arguing and fighting with one another.
the mother of all, mostly referred to the old mother of all the dogs and puppies.
a snell wind. Ransach de ghaoith a tuath.
a trifling amount given to somebody. (deirg or pension)
in a clean sweep. Thog e e sgudail glan.
(lamh chrann) a thin pole, used for the handle of a suisde, as a rule.
a palmful of water. Cuir badlach [sic] air t-aodann.
getting odds and ends, particularly of items of clothing.
drying, esp. drinking the dregs of a bottle. Drudhadh a bhotuil.
(Eochdar) selecting. Tha mi siamachadh an iomaire seo airson buntata a chur ann.
a lot of beef for eating. Tha roic agabh [sic].
from corner to corner. Tha an t-seal air bheannabh – shawl.
ploughing a rig starting from the outside.
ploughing a rig starting in the middle.
goireadh (gurradh) air a cheile – wrangling with one another.
struggling with a job, taking too long to it.
a sudden gust of wind; squall.
rolling over. A horse scratching its back. Tha an t-each ga aonraigich fhein.
the strap across a horse’s back to hold up the sintean [q.v.].
the chains or ropes from the hames to the swindle-trees.
other way of saying treabhadh, hence sintean [q.v.].
trench. Trinnse a mhuilinn – the waterway to the mill wheel.
Michaelmas cake, made with a bannock covered on each side with some form of sweet, such as treacle and flour.
the last egg or even the first which is very small.
smallest drop. Cha do dhol [sic] e shirc an diugh.
wasting time like a slow coach.
udagag, an adagag, a ghobhar athar, a lionarag ’s a’ naoisg. (In Uist the various names of the one bird – the lionarag.)
(scryj) an untidy woman; a large flat button.
a bruising on the toe knocked against a stone.
pulled off without hesitation. Thug e as e sgudail glan.
Cean-dubh air a gheallaich – the turn after the moon has been full.
a session, such as: Thug e spealeatrom air a phiob or Thug i spealeatrom air trod.
biting a piece in a course [sic] way.
feadan na bathchadh or the claise.
a criathar without holes, usually used for holding wool in rollagan.
thankless. Nach ann ort a bha don-gnothaich (if you did a job that was not asked for).
like a split pin used in cart wheels to keep them on the axle.
throwing flat stanes [sic] along the surface of the lock [sic].
used by some people for means of travel. Theid mi ann ma dheibh [sic] mi ais [sic].
a small uncouth fellow, usually cheeky.
a sudden pull. Thug e spointeadh air a’ ropa.
an ear piper, one who has just picked it up on his own.
handle of a pot or pan, usually a wire one.
in the fank pulling the ewes and other sheep out to be dipped or sheared. ’S e na feadhainn oga bhiodh a crogadh.
getting the cattle housed for the winter, and also getting the harvest in, hence deireadh chrodhaidh.
the rafters on a thatched house.
the corner pole on the roof of a thatched house.
the middle pole [on the roof of a thatched house].
a small fank where the calves and lambs were placed to separate them from their mothers.
a big untidy lump, often applied to a fat untidy woman.
the part above the hip of an animal (the hollow).
conceit. Tha e lan sparuig. – he is full of himself.
used for beating the grain, to break off the husks.
the complete thing, buailtean [q.v.] and handle.
looking angry. Tha cold fiobhaich air a chu.
making room, as working oneself into a crowded seat.
having an itchy upper lip meant that one would get an unexpected dram.
a rangy or bony animal (applied [to] the tall round-shouldered men).
put on the spot. Bha mi ann an cuil chumhaig [sic].
a sort of bra for spilling oats (a flat stone with a hold [sic] in it where the grain was put for spilling).
